data.title: Remember My Name (1978)
data.meta_description: Just released from prison, a young woman arrives in town to "start a new life," but soon begins stalking a married construction worker for no apparent reason, turning his life inside out and eventually terrorizing him and his wife.
data.text:
“Remember My Name” is a lethargic late 70s entry bleached out by the high intensity rays of the past.

Director Alan Rudolph’s work, about a woman who leaves prison and sets off to worsen her prior mistakes, is very much a producer’s film.

While that phrase is typically more an accusation than a desired trait - it is not so in this case.

Because in this case — the producer is Robert Altman.

“Name,” which even stars Altman regulars Jeff Goldblum and Geraldine Chaplin, feels like a lo fi version of the “Nashville” legend’s work.

The film has none of the Altman-esque frenetic overlapping conversations or blasts of sound and chaos. It’s almost as if someone took one background character…

Lock him up, lock the door, and throw away the key. Alan Rudolph's inside-out thriller is like an extended embodiment of one of those Alberta Hunter blues that keep looping throughout. The story of a wronged woman's love and loyalty lost, and the path she took to get it back—to be shared with no one else but herself. Betrayal jammed right back into the mouths (Anthony Perkins, the prison system, overpriced drinks charged to fuckbois) that spit it out. Even in a miserable world of countless deaths (the hopelessly inadequate TV discussion of a million dead in a Budapest earthquake makes this, in 2020, an eerily apt quarantine view), here's a reminder of life's grace notes, of the whole goddamn…
